prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a total of 4.86 hours in ALMA 12-m + ACA combination with band-6 to image the dust continuum emission, 12CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1), and C18O (2-1) toward the Oph A region.
Requested sensitivity: Continuum: Four spectral windows in the line-free region of bandpass will be allocated for the continuum data. The total bandwidth is 3.98 GHz. From our previous AzTEC/ASTE observations, the peak continuum emission at 270 GHz was about 5Jy/35'' beam, which corresponds to about 18 mJy/2."5 beam at 230 GHz, assuming that the dust opacity is proportional to the square of the frequency (beta=2). The achieved sensitivity is estimated to be ~0.25 mJy/beam for the continuum, corresponding to the S/N ~75.
12CO, 13CO, C18O: We expect the C18O (the weakest among three CO lines) intensity to be at least similar to that in the single dish data of 2-3K. Since the line widths of the typical cores are about 0.5 km/s, we require the velocity resolution of about 0.1 km/s. Therefore, for these lines, the sensitivity of 0.25 K rms with 0.1 km/s velocity resolution is required to achieve S/N > 12.
According to the OT time calculation tool, it takes 4.86 hours (0.97 hour and 3.89 hours for the 12-m array and ACA observations) to image Oph A wit the 2.''5 resolution.

Correlator setup: The spectral setup contains five windows. Three windows are centered at the center frequency of 12CO J=2-1 in USB (bandwidth =117.188 MHz), 13CO J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz), C18O J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz). The other two windows are allocated for the continuum observations, centered at the frequein LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz)cy of 234 GHz and 218 GHz with a 2 GHz bandwidth in the USB and LSB, respectively. C18O emission sometimes has narrow line width of 0.5km/s or less. To resolve this line width, we require 0.1km/s velocity resolution. For 13CO and 12CO, we set similar resolutions to that of C18O. This does not change the total observation time so much.
OT suggests that 12CO and 13CO are near the baseband edges and the sensitivities are not so good. But, these two lines are expected to be much stronger than C18O and we expect better S/N for these two lines.

Imaging Requirement: We will make a mosaic observation to cover the dense part of Oph A with 150 12-m pointings. We request ACA because the structure is extended to about 20", according to previous observations. To cover the target area with S/N > 10 for molecular lines in a reasonable observation time, the angular resolution of the synthesized map is chosen to be 2''.5. This resolution is comparable to that of Nakamura et al. (2012, see Figure 2). Therefore, we can detect similar structures in the clump, if exist.

We request a total of 4.84 hours in ALMA 12-m + ACA combination with band-6 to image the dust continuum emission, 12CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1), and C18O (2-1) toward the Oph B2 region.
Requested sensitivity: Continuum: Four spectral windows in the line-free region of bandpass will be allocated for the continuum data. The total bandwidth is 3.98 GHz. From our previous AzTEC/ASTE observations, the peak continuum emission at 270 GHz was about 1.6Jy/35'' beam, which corresponds to about 6 mJy/2."5 beam at 230 GHz, assuming that the dust opacity is proportional to the square of the frequency (beta=2). The achieved sensitivity is estimated to be ~0.25 mJy/beam for the continuum, corresponding to the S/N ~12.
12CO, 13CO, C18O: We expect the C18O (the weakest among three CO lines) intensity to be at least similar to that in the single dish data of 2-3K. Since the line widths of the typical cores are about 0.5 km/s, we require the velocity resolution of about 0.1 km/s. Therefore, for these lines, the sensitivity of 0.25 K rms with 0.1 km/s velocity resolution is required to achieve S/N > 12.
According to the OT time calculation tool, it takes 4.84 hours (0.97 hours and 3.87 hours for the 12-m array and ACA observations) to image Oph B2 wit the 2.''5 resolution.

Correlator setup: The spectral setup contains five windows. Three windows are centered at the center frequency of 12CO J=2-1 in USB (bandwidth =117.188 MHz), 13CO J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz), C18O J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz). The other two windows are allocated for the continuum observations, centered at the frequein LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz)cy of 234 GHz and 218 GHz with a 2 GHz bandwidth in the USB and LSB, respectively.
C18O emission sometimes has narrow line width of 0.5km/s or less. To resolve this line width, we require 0.1km/s velocity resolution. For 13CO and 12CO, we set similar resolutions to that of C18O. This does not change the total observation time so much.
OT suggests that 12CO and 13CO are near the baseband edges and the sensitivities are not so good. But, these two lines are expected to be much stronger than C18O and we expect better S/N for these two lines.

Imaging Requirement: We will make a mosaic observation to cover the dense part of Oph B2 with 149 12-m pointings. We request ACA because the structure is extended to about 20", according to previous observations. To cover the target area with S/N > 10 for molecular lines in a reasonable observation time, the angular resolution of the synthesized map is chosen to be 2''.5.

We request a total of 4.58 hours in ALMA 12-m + ACA combination with band-6 to image the dust continuum emission, 12CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1), and C18O (2-1) toward the Oph C region.
Requested sensitivity: Continuum: Four spectral windows in the line-free region of bandpass will be allocated for the continuum data. The total bandwidth is 3.98 GHz. From our previous AzTEC/ASTE observations, the peak continuum emission at 270 GHz was about 1.4Jy/35'' beam, which corresponds to about 5 mJy/2."5 beam at 230 GHz, assuming that the dust opacity is proportional to the square of the frequency (beta=2). The achieved sensitivity is estimated to be ~0.25 mJy/beam for the continuum, corresponding to the S/N ~10.
12CO, 13CO, C18O: We expect the C18O (the weakest among three CO lines) intensity to be at least similar to that in the single dish data of 2-3K. Since the line widths of the typical cores are about 0.5 km/s, we require the velocity resolution of about 0.1 km/s. Therefore, for these lines, the sensitivity of 0.25 K rms with 0.1 km/s velocity resolution is required to achieve S/N > 12.
OT suggests that 12CO and 13CO are near the baseband edges and the sensitivities are not so good. But, these two lines are expected to be much stronger than C18O and we expect better S/N for these two lines.
According to the OT time calculation tool, it takes 4.58 hours (0.92 hours and 3.66 hours for the 12-m array and ACA observations) to image Oph C wit the 2.''5 resolution.

Correlator setup: The spectral setup contains five windows. Three windows are centered at the center frequency of 12CO J=2-1 in USB (bandwidth =117.188 MHz), 13CO J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz), C18O J=2-1 in LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz). The other two windows are allocated for the continuum observations, centered at the frequein LSB (bandpath=58.594 MHz)cy of 234 GHz and 218 GHz with a 2 GHz bandwidth in the USB and LSB, respectively.
C18O emission sometimes has narrow line width of 0.5km/s or less. To resolve this line width, we require 0.1km/s velocity resolution. For 13CO and 12CO, we set similar resolutions to that of C18O. This does not change the total observation time so much.
OT suggests that 12CO and 13CO are near the baseband edges and the sensitivities are not so good. But, these two lines are expected to be much stronger than C18O and we expect better S/N for these two lines.

Imaging Requirement: We will make a mosaic observation to cover the dense part of Oph C with 138 12-m pointings. We request ACA because the structure is extended to about 20", , according to previous observations. To cover the target area with S/N > 10 for molecular lines in a reasonable observation time, the angular resolution of the synthesized map is chosen to be 2''.5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The origin of the stellar IMF is a fundamental unresolved problem in star formation. Recent millimeter and submillimeter observations of the rho Ophiuchus cluster-forming region uncovered prestellar cores with a mass spectrum (hereafter, CMF) that resembles the Salpeter IMF. The implication is that the IMF may be determined to a large extent by the core mass distribution from cloud fragmentation.
However, the low-mass ends ( < 0.1 Msolar) of the CMFs remain to be elucidated observationally because of the lack of high spatial resolution observations. In order to clarify the link between the CMFs and IMF, it is crucial to derive the low-mass end of the CMFs. Here, we propose mosaic observations toward the dense regions of the nearest cluster-forming region, rho Ophiuchus, at a distance of 120 pc.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is the same proposal as we submitted at cycle 2 and ranked B category. By April 15th, the ACA observations have completed and the 7-m data are delivered, but the 12-m observations haven't started yet. So, we resubmit the proposal to cycle 3. We note that the ACA data with 5"-7" resolusion are consistent with the images of Figure 2. For example, we detected a1 and a3 condensations in the Oph A region.
